messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "C. Paige Gabhart"
<pgabhart@c...> wrote:
> But what is necessary is communication. The only reason to be
concerned
> whether there is a "standard" spelling is if it negatively affects
> communication. I do not believe it will prevent people from
deciphering
> words written in QS since language is full of redundancies. Nor do
I
> believe it will even slow a person's reading speed appreciably once
they
> have attained QS fluency.

This is the reactive interpretation of a principle that also has a
proactive interpretation -- namely, that spelling can be standardized
to *positively* affect communication. It's touched on briefly in the
Quikscript manual wrt the 'R' glyph, it's always included in
spellings, even though the RP, which usually guides Mr. Read's
spellings, usually doesn't pronounce it, because it helps distinguish
the words "saw" and "sore," as the example in the text gives.

I suppose the logical, ethnically neutral thing to do would be to go
through either (or both) of the pronunciation databases, strip them
of all vowels, and then sort them s.t. similar series of consonantal
noises are listed near-consecutively. One could then assign more or
less arbitrary vowels that are close, even if not exactly, to how it
is pronounced in at least one dialect, s.t. spelling differences
between near-homonyms is maximized in an efficient manner with a
minimum of non-phoneticism.

Alas, my programmatical, statistical, and linguistic skills are
insufficient for doing this either by hand or automatically, and my
political skills are entirely inadequate for deciding which words,
when changed vocalically, are too far from the actual pronunciation
to be justified. Changing the vowels of bear and bare, for example,
to facilitate reading might be a little farfetched. Or not.
